questions.text: A patient presented with a deformity as shown in the image below. What is this deformity known as?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the midline of the dorsum of the nose from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner which is known as crooked nose deformity.

 

Option B: Deviated nose - midline is straight but deviated to one side.

Option C: Hump nose is due to excess of bony or cartilaginous dorsum.

Option D: Saddle nose is depressed nasal dorsum.

questions.text: In which of the following patients will you not expect a saddle nose deformity?

choices.text: A VDRL positive patient with gumma of the nasal septum
A patient with lateral madarosis and leonine facies
A boxer who developed bilateral nasal obstruction after a trauma to the nose
A patient with growth hormone excess and a large nose.

questions.solution:
Option D is a case of acromegaly, in which there may be enlargement of the nose. Saddle nose deformity only occurs when the bridge of the nose collapses.

Causes for saddle nose/depressed dorsum of nose:

  • Nasal trauma causing depressed fractures - most common etiology.
  • Excessive removal of septum in submucous resection
  • Destruction of septal cartilage by haematoma or abscess
  • Leprosy
  • Syphilis
  • Tuberculosis.

Option A is a case of tertiary syphilis.

Option B is a case of lepromatous leprosy.

Option C is a case of septal hematoma.

questions.text: A newborn developed respiratory distress immediately after delivery. The paediatrician was unable to pass the nasogastric tube through both the nares. Which of the following statements is false about the above diagnosis?

choices.text: It is due to persistence of bucconasal membrane
Can be associated with CHARGE syndrome.
Bony obstruction is more common than membranous obstruction
Immediate tracheostomy to be done to maintain the airway.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of bilateral choanal atresia and immediate tracheostomy is not indicated.

Simply securing a feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway and forces the infant to breathe through the mouth. This is known as McGovern’s technique and obviates the need for tracheostomy.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx. It has the following features:

  • Bony obstruction is more common than membranous
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.

CT scan is the investigation of choice

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

Immediate management involves placing a feeding nipple with a large hole at the mouth to force the baby to mouth-breathe - McGoverns technique.

Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought with a soft, compressible swelling at the root of the nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of isolated solitary mass arising from the root of the nose should raise the index of suspicion of nasal meningocele or meningoencephalocele. It is the herniation of brain tissue along with its meninges through a congenital bony defect.

Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. It presents as a cystic, bluish, compressible, translucent mass at the root of the nose (nasofrontal variety), side of the nose (nasoethmoid variety), or at the anteromedial aspect of the orbit (nasoorbital variety).

Furstenberg's test: compression of the ipsilateral internal jugular vein usually causes an encephalocele to enlarge.

Investigation: CT or MRI.

Treatment: Transnasal endoscopic excision with the closure of the defect using bone or cartilage graft along with temporalis fascia and fat.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about nasal glioma is false?
questions.solution:
There is no CSF leakage in nasal glioma. It is a nipped-off portion of an encephalocele with no communication with the cranial cavity.

They usually present as a firm, subcutaneous swelling causing nasal obstruction.

Furstenberg's test - compression of the ipsilateral internal jugular vein usually causes an encephalocele to enlarge, but not a glioma. So, this test is negative in nasal glioma.

60% of nasal gliomas are extra-nasal, 30% are intranasal, and 10% are both intranasal and extra-nasal. 

CT scan reveals bony details while MRI reveals soft tissue details of a nasal glioma.

questions.text: A surgeon suspects a rodent ulcer in a patient who presented with a finding as shown in the image.  What is this condition also called?
questions.solution: Basal cell carcinoma also known as rodent ulcer is the most common malignant tumour involving skin of nose.

questions.text: In a patient with findings as shown in the image, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: It is known as elephantiasis of the nose
It is seen in long standing cases of acne rosacea
It is commonly seen in middle aged women
It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands

questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of rhinophyma. It is commonly seen in men past middle age.

Rhinophyma or potato tumour or elephantiasis of nose is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands. It is usually associated with long-standing cases of acne rosacea. Mostly seen at the tip of the nose and causes unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision. 

Treatment: Debulk of the tumor with carbon dioxide laser and the area is allowed to re-epithelialize. Sometimes the tumor is completely excised and skin is grafted over the raw area.

questions.text: A patient presented with atrophic dry nasal mucosa, extensive crustations, and a woody hard external nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages:

  • Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.
  • Granulomatous stage– Painless, non ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving feel of woody/hebra nose.
  • Cicatricial stage– Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. Deformity is called tapir nose.

Option A: Atrophic rhinitis doesn’t cause woody nose.

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumor is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A pathologist observed Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies on microscopy in a biopsy specimen taken from the nose. Which of the following is a false statement regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Medical management include streptomycin and tetracycline.
Surgery is the treatment of choice for this disease

questions.solution:
Biopsy findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell's bodies are characteristic findings in rhinoscleroma. Medical management is the mainstay treatment for rhinoscleroma. Streptomycin(1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given for a minimum of 4-6 weeks and continued till 2 consecutive biopsies are negative. Surgery is reserved to establish airway or correct deformity.

Biopsy in the case of rhinoscleroma shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. 

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli.

Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. They occur due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells.

The following image shows rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells.

H&E showing a mixture of plasma cells (arrow), lymphocytes (short arrow), Miculikz cells which are vacuolated macrophages containing causative bacilli (double arrow).

Option A: Rhinoscleroma is endemic in several parts of the world. In India, it is seen more often in the northern than in the southern parts. 

Option D: Organism can be cultured from biopsy material.

questions.text: Snuffles are seen in which stage of syphilis?
questions.solution:
Snuffles is seen in early congenital syphilis.

Nasal features in different stages of syphilis:

Stage  Feature 
Early congenital syphilis Snuffles
Late congenital syphilis Gumma on the nasal septum
Primary syphilis Primary chancre of the vestibule of nose
Secondary syphilis Simple rhinitis with crusting and fissuring in the nasal vestibule
Tertiary form of acquired syphilis Gumma on the nasal septum

questions.text: An eighteen-year-old boy presented with a lesion over the nose as shown in the image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows apple jelly nodules seen in lupus vulgaris which is a low-grade tuberculous infection.

These are brown, gelatinous nodules commonly affecting nasal vestibule or the skin of nose and face.

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of a biopsy taken from a farmer who presented with a vascular polypoidal mass protruding from his left nostril. What is the causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histology (showing sporangia) is suggestive of rhinosporidiosis caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi.

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

questions.text: Rhinosporidium seeberi belongs to which group of organisms?
questions.solution:
Rhinosporidium seeberi is an aquatic protista.

Molecular biological techniques have demonstrated that this organism is an aquatic protistan parasite and it is currently included in a new class, the Mesomycetozoea, along with organisms causing similar infections in amphibians and fish.

questions.text: A man who works in a cattle ranch presented with complaints of a mass protruding from the left nostril and blood-stained nasal discharge. The mass is pink, leafy, and polypoidal and is attached to the nasal septum. Biopsy from the lesion showed several sporangia. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Surgical management (excision of the lesion with cauterisation of the base), is always the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis.

No drug treatment has proved effective, although dapsone is tried in some cases. Followup of the patient after surgical management is necessary, as recurrence is common.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about nasal T-cell lymphoma?

choices.text: It is also known as Stewart’s granulomas
It is a locally invasive tumor.
Surgery is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
T-cell lymphoma is treated by radiation when it is localised and by chemotherapy when it is disseminated.

The condition is also called as:

  • Non-healing midline granuloma 
  • Midline granulomas reticulosis 
  • Stewart’s granuloma 
  • Nasal T-cell lymphoma
  • Lethal midline granuloma

It is associated with EBV. Cells express T cell markers like CD56.

Nasal obstruction and epistaxis are the presenting features. Destruction of mid-facial structures may be caused by the local invasion.

Histologically, polymorphic lymphoid tissue with angiocentric and angioinvasive features are seen.
